This paper focuses on the choice of the optimal pore size and the effect of pore size dispersion, which is important for the rational design of nanoporous supercapacitors. Optimization of the pore size of nanoporous carbon electrodes is discussed in terms of the maximal stored energy d. By applying a previously developed theory, and supporting it by newly performed expts., we find that the energy d. is a non-monotonic function of the pore size of monodisperse porous electrodes. The optimal' pore size that provides the maximal energy d. increases with increasing operating voltage and sats. at high voltages. We also analyze how the pore size distribution affects the voltage dependent capacitance and the stored energy d., and show that the latter is maximized for monodisperse electrodes.

Tubular structured ordered mesoporous C CMK-5 was investigated for the adsorption of the industrial dyes Reactive Blue 19, Acid Red 57 and Fuchsin Basic in aq. solns. at room temp. It was found that CMK-5 exhibits an ultrahigh adsorption rate and superior adsorption capacities for these dyes. Its max. adsorption capacities for Reactive Blue 19, Acid Red 57 and Fuchsin Basic were 733, 1131 and 1403 mg/g, resp., and significantly greater than other literature reported results on porous carbons. Following adsorption of Reactive Blue 19, CMK-5 C could be regenerated by either ethanol extn. or thermal annealing at 600°, reaching ∼51 and ∼77%, resp., of the adsorption capacity of the original C. For comparison, ordered mesoporous C CMK-3 (rod structure), polymer based disordered mesoporous C, and steam and CO2 activated com. coconut carbons were studied for the adsorption of Reactive Blue 19. The fast adsorption rate of CMK-5 C is due to its unique properties of tubular mesostructure, bimodal mesopore system and high surface area. In the case of requiring emergency removal of large amt. of dyes in aq. soln., CMK-5 would be an ideal choice.

Ordered mesoporous carbons (OMCs) were synthesized in the pore system of SBA-15 aluminosilicates with different Si/Al ratios ranging from 5 to 80. Nitrogen adsorption was used to characterize the pore structure of the aluminosilicates and of the OMCs, whereas the OMC surface chem. was studied by XPS and static secondary ion mass spectroscopy. The results indicate that the physicochem. properties of the OMCs depended significantly on the acid catalytic activity of the aluminosilicate frameworks, which comes along with the variation of Si/Al ratios. The OMC pore widths and order of the graphene layers followed the same trend as the catalytic activity of the aluminosilicates, whereas the concn. of extra framework species in the aluminosilicates indirectly influenced the mech. properties of the OMCs. The reasons for this behavior are discussed.

Ordered mesoporous carbon with hexagonal arrays of tubes (CMK-5) was successfully synthesized via a nanocasting process by directly using SBA-15, instead of AlSBA-15, as a template, furfuryl alc. as a carbon source and oxalic acid as the catalyst. The time consuming impregnation of SBA-15 with aluminum could be saved. The as-synthesized CMK-5 exhibits a tubular structure with double pore system. The loading amt. of carbon precursor on the pore walls of SBA-15 is the key factor for the formation of the CMK-5 structure with two-dimensional hexagonal arrays of tubes, and the pore diam. can be adjusted by varying the loading amt. of the carbon precursor. The CMK-5 carbon exhibits high apparent surface area up to ∼2500 m2/g and high pore vol. reaching ∼2 cm3/g, which is due to the unique structure of CMK-5. The characterization results confirmed that carbonization under argon atm. instead of vacuum is sufficient for the structural formation of CMK-5 carbons, and can be used as an alternative pathway to prep. tubular-type carbons.

Ordered mesoporous carbons with controllable pore size distributions were prepd. by mesostructured SBA-15 silica samples as templates. By varying the prepn. temp. of SBA-15 between 90 and 150°, it is possible to tune the size of silica mesopores between 7.2 and 11.3 nm. As the prepn. temp. of SBA-15 silica increases over this range, the size of the mesopores of templated carbons can be modified between 3.0 and 5.2 nm. Modification of the prepn. temp. of silica does not affect its structural order, which is that characteristic of SBA-15. Independent of the type of SBA-15 used as template, the prepd. carbons are highly ordered. The porosity of the carbons prepd. from SBA-15 silica in one impregnation-carbonization (N2) cycle is made up of 2 types of mesopores, i.e. structural mesopores (derived from the silica skeleton) and mesopores confined within the carbon rods. The structure of a carbon with these characteristics is described by the CMK-3/5 model, which is presented here for the first time. When the impregnation-carbonisation cycle is repeated twice, the carbon rod confined mesopores disappear and the structure of the resulting carbon is well described by the CMK-3 model.

SBA-15 ordered mesoporous silicas were synthesized. The structures of these materials were characterized using powder XRD, TGA, and N adsorption. The samples exhibit structural properties similar to those reported earlier. The size of primary mesopores of SBA-15 can be tailored by the choice of synthesis temp. That SBA-15 exhibits a significant amt. of disordered micropores and small mesopores. The vol. and size of these complementary pores are dependent to some extent on the synthesis/aging temp. The washing of as-synthesized SBA-15 in H2O or EtOH was accompanied by an appreciable structural shrinkage and led to the removal of a significant part of the polymeric template. Therefore, washing needs to be avoided if one wants to isolate SBA-15 without appreciable loss of the template. H2O-washed SBA-15 samples have fully accessible primary mesopores. EtOH-washed samples also exhibit accessible porosity. Despite an appreciable content of the template in the H2O- and EtOH-washed samples, their pore sizes were usually larger than those of the calcined materials. The obsd. structural properties of SBA-15 and their dependence on the synthesis temp. and washing were attributed to the changes in the degree of penetration of the poly(ethylene oxide) chains of the triblock copolymer template within the siliceous walls of SBA-15.

A graphene-based supercapacitor electrode suitable for ionic liq. electrolytes was designed and prepd. based on the electrostatic interactions between neg. charged graphene oxides (GO) and pos. charged mesoporous C CMK-5 platelets. Thermal annealing of the GO-CMK-5 composite under an inert atm. yielded a hierarchical C nanostructure with CMK-5 platelets uniformly intercalated between the GO sheets. The electrochem. results demonstrated that the CMK-5 platelets with straight and short mesochannels served as a highway for the fast transport of electrolyte ions, while the sepd. graphene sheets with more exposed electrochem. surface area favored the formation of elec. double layer capacitance. The RGO-CMK-5 electrode exhibited a specific capacitance of 144.4 F g-1 in 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate ionic liq. electrolyte, which can be charged/discharged at an operating voltage of 3.5 V. As a result, an energy d. of 60.7 W h kg-1 and a power d. ≤10 kW kg-1 were achieved, which outperforms most of the present graphene-based supercapacitors. Also, the superior rate performance together with the excellent cycle performance makes the RGO-CMK-5 composite a promising candidate for next generation supercapacitor electrodes.

Broader applications of carbon nanotubes to real-world problems have largely gone unfulfilled because of difficult material synthesis and laborious processing. We report high-performance multifunctional carbon nanotube (CNT) fibers that combine the specific strength, stiffness, and thermal cond. of carbon fibers with the specific elec. cond. of metals. These fibers consist of bulk-grown CNTs and are produced by high-throughput wet spinning, the same process used to produce high-performance industrial fibers. These scalable CNT fibers are positioned for high-value applications, such as aerospace electronics and field emission, and can evolve into engineered materials with broad long-term impact, from consumer electronics to long-range power transmission.

A novel and effective method was described in this work to prep. two-dimensional hexagonally ordered mesoporous CMK-5 carbon materials. This method is based on the chem. vapor deposition (CVD) of ferrocene in the mesopores of SBA-15 at 500 °C, followed by graphitization at different temps. Both the silica/carbon composite and the resulting CMK-5 were characterized by N2 adsorption, powder X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, transmission electron microscopy, high-resoln. transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), and thermogravimetric anal. It was found that the ferrocene could be used as a new precursor to prep. CMK-5 nanopipes, with pipe thicknesses varying from 0.8 to 2.6 nm, by increasing the CVD time from 20 to 120 min. The resulting CMK-5 exhibits high Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area (1044-2449 m2/g) and large pore vol. (1.13-2.20 cm3/g). The graphitization degree of the resulting CMK-5 was investigated by pyrolyzing the corresponding silica/carbon composite at different temps. Pyrolysis temps. below 850 °C led to gradually improved graphitization degrees of CMK-5 nanopipes. Pyrolysis temps. above 850 °C resulted in the partial collapse of ordered CMK-5 nanopipes accompanied by the appearance of a considerable amt. of entangled graphitic ribbons. The structural evolution process of CMK-5 from ordered nanopipes to the final entangled graphitic ribbons was obsd. by HRTEM. The obtained CMK-5 was applied as a catalyst support of Pt for methanol oxidn. The electrochem. activities of Pt nanoparticles loaded on the CMK-5 carbon materials were investigated by cyclic voltammograms and compared with the com. Pt/Vulcan XC-72 catalyst. It was found that the specific mass activity of Pt/CMK-5 was much higher than Pt/Vulcan XC-72.

As an anode for Li-ion intercalation, the CMK-5 matrix could not only provide sufficient space to buffer the vol. change of MoSe2 during the charge-discharge process, but also increase the elec. cond. and shorten the lithium-ion diffusion pathway. It was found that the MoSe2/CMK-5 composite exhibited an outstanding specific capacity of 788 mA h g-1 at a c.d. of 100 mA g-1 and excellent high rate performance. More importantly, a capacity of 451 mA h g-1 could be retained after 1000 cycles even at a c.d. as high as 2000 mA g-1, indicating that such a composite has long-term cycling stability.

High-frequency electrochemical capacitors based on plasma pyrolyzed bacterial cellulose aerogel for current ripple filtering and pulse energy storage
Islam, Nazifah; Li, Shiqi; Ren, Guofeng; Zu, Yujiao; Warzywoda, Juliusz; Wang, Shu; Fan, Zhaoyang

There are great needs in developing compact-size kilohertz (kHz) high-frequency (HF) electrochem. capacitors (ECs) for ripple current filtering and environmental vibration energy harvesting. However, the previously demonstrated electrodes are generally limited to a very small areal capacitance d. at 120 Hz due to sub-μm thick electrode used for meeting frequency requirement, which renders them unsuitable for practical ECs. Here, using crosslinked carbon nanofiber aerogel, derived from rapid microwave plasma pyrolysis of bacterial cellulose that was synthesized in a fermn. process, we demonstrated kHz HF-ECs with areal capacitance d. as high as 4.5 mF cm-2 at 120 Hz in an aq. electrolyte. The cruciality of plasma pyrolysis on high frequency response of the derived carbon nanofiber aerogel was discussed. The electrode performance in an org. electrolyte was further studied for operation in a large potential window of more than 3 V. Using such kHz HF-ECs, we further demonstrated their applications in rapid pulse energy storage for vibrational energy harvesting, as well as in ripple current filtering for AC/DC conversion. The promising results suggest this technol. has great potential for developing practical compact HF-ECs in substitution of electrolytic capacitors for several crucial applications.

High-frequency electrochem. capacitors or elec. double layer capacitor (HF-ECs) with large capacitance were developed from edge-oriented graphene (EOG) nanosheets perpendicularly grown around carbonized cellulose microfiber (CMF) sheets. Binder-free EOG/CMF electrodes were fabricated in a one-step 5-min plasma-enhanced chem. vapor deposition process, where cellulose fiber sheets were rapidly pyrolyzed by high-temp. plasma, while EOG simultaneously formed on the developing CMFs. Owing to combined unique characteristics of both EOG and CMF, such facilely produced electrodes exhibit excellent performance in terms of both high frequency response and high capacitance d. In aq. electrolyte cells, 10 μm thick EOG/CMF electrode exhibits an areal capacitance of 1.07 mF cm-2 at 120 Hz along with a frequency of 13.8 kHz at -45° phase angle. ∼3 V org. electrolyte cells show an areal capacitance of 0.49 mF cm-2 at 120 Hz, and a frequency of 1.47 kHz at -45° phase angle. Developed HF-ECs were successfully applied in practical applications as ripple current filter in line-frequency AC/DC conversion, and as pulse power storage/smoother in environmental energy harvesting for self-powered micro devices.

High-frequency supercapacitors based on doped carbon nanostructures
Han, Zhao Jun; Huang, Chun; Meysami, Seyyed Shayan; Piche, Dominique; Seo, Dong Han; Pineda, Shafique; Murdock, Adrian T.; Bruce, Peter S.; Grant, Patrick S.; Grobert, Nicole

C nanostructures are promising materials for electrochem. energy storage but their frequency response is usually poor, limiting their use in high-frequency applications. Here we demonstrate the growth of C nanostructures with different dopants of N, B, P/N, B/N, and Si, based on a scalable aerosol-assisted CVD process. The doped C nanostructures were directly grown on the conductive Ni substrates and exhibit an open and porous structure which is beneficial for fast ion transport and ion kinetics. Coin cells made of the doped C nanostructures demonstrate a frequency response as fast as 13,200 Hz at a phase angle of -45° and the smallest relaxation time const. of ∼77 μs. Together with a low equiv. series resistance and a large areal capacitance, the high-frequency supercapacitors based on doped C nanostructures could be promising in replacing traditional Al electrolytic capacitors for many high-frequency electronic devices.

Ultrahigh-rate supercapacitors with large capacitance based on edge oriented graphene coated carbonized cellulous paper as flexible freestanding electrodes
Ren, Guofeng; Li, Shiqi; Fan, Zhao-Xia; Hoque, Md. Nadim Ferdous; Fan, Zhaoyang
Journal of Power Sources

Large-capacitance and ultrahigh-rate electrochem. supercapacitors (UECs) with frequency response up to kilohertz (kHz) range are reported using light, thin, and flexible freestanding electrodes. The electrode is formed by perpendicularly edge oriented multilayer graphene/thin-graphite (EOG) sheets grown radially around individual fibers in carbonized cellulous paper (CCP), with cellulous carbonization and EOG deposition implemented in one step. The resulted ∼10 μm thick EOG/CCP electrode is light and flexible. The oriented porous structure of EOG with large surface area, in conjunction with high cond. of the electrode, ensures ultrahigh-rate performance of the fabricated cells, with large areal capacitance of 0.59 mF cm-2 and 0.53 mF cm-2 and large phase angle of -83° and -80° at 120 Hz and 1 kHz, resp. Particularly, the hierarchical EOG/CCP sheet structure allows multiple sheets stacked together for thick electrodes with almost linearly increased areal capacitance while maintaining the volumetric capacitance nearly no degrdn., a crit. merit for developing practical faraday-scale UECs. 3-layers of EOG/CCP electrode achieved an areal capacitance of 1.5 mF cm-2 and 1.4 mF cm-2 at 120 Hz and 1 kHz, resp. This demonstration moves a step closer to the goal of bridging the frequency/capacitance gap between supercapacitors and electrolytic capacitors.

High-frequency supercapacitors are being stud- ied with the aim to replace the bulky electrolytic capacitors for current ripple filtering and other functions used in power systems. Here, 3D edge-oriented graphene (EOG) was grown encircling carbon nanofiber (CNF) framework to form a highly conductive electrode with a large surface area. Such EOG/CNF electrodes were tested in aq. and org. electrolytes for high-frequency supercapacitor development. For the aq. and the org. cell, the characteristic frequency at - 45° phase angle was found to be as high as 22 and 8.5 kHz, resp. At 120 Hz, the electrode capacitance d. was 0.37 and 0.16 mF cm-2 for the two cells. In particular, the 3 V high-frequency org. cell was successfully tested as filtering capacitor used in AC/DC converter, suggesting the promising potential of this technol. for compact power supply design and other applications.
